title: Grace and Unity in Christ
shortSummary: Ephesians chapter 2 reveals the transformative power of God's grace, moving believers from spiritual death to life through faith in Christ. It emphasizes salvation as a gift, not earned by works, and highlights the breaking down of barriers between Jews and Gentiles, uniting them into one new body in Christ.
timeline: c. AD 60 - Written by the Apostle Paul during his imprisonment in Rome

keyCharacters.name: Paul
keyCharacters.description: The Apostle who authored Ephesians, teaching about salvation by grace and the unity of believers in Christ.

keyCharacters.name: Christ Jesus
keyCharacters.description: The Savior who quickens the spiritually dead, raises believers, and reconciles Jews and Gentiles into one body.

keyCharacters.name: Gentiles
keyCharacters.description: Non-Jewish believers who were once alienated from God but are now brought near through Christ's blood.

keyCharacters.name: Jews
keyCharacters.description: God’s chosen people, who were once separated from Gentiles but are now united with them in the church.

definitions.definition: Made alive spiritually; refers to God giving life to those who were dead in sin.
Unmerited favor from God, the means by which believers are saved, not by works.
Hostility or opposition; here it refers to the division between Jews and Gentiles abolished by Christ.
The community or nation of Israel, God's chosen people under the Old Covenant.
The foundational stone in a building; Jesus is the chief cornerstone of the church, the foundation of faith.

outline.heading: From Death to Life by Grace
outline.description: Paul describes humanity's former spiritual death due to sin and disobedience, and God's rich mercy that brings believers to life and raises them up with Christ by grace.

outline.heading: Salvation Is a Gift, Not by Works
outline.description: Salvation is explained as a gift from God received through faith, not earned by human works, and believers are created for good works prepared by God.

outline.heading: Gentiles Brought Near to God
outline.description: Paul reminds Gentile believers of their former alienation from God and the promises, but now they are brought near through the blood of Christ.

outline.heading: Christ Breaks Down Dividing Walls
outline.description: Christ is our peace who abolishes enmity between Jews and Gentiles, creating one new man and granting both access to the Father by one Spirit.

outline.heading: The Church: One Household and Holy Temple
outline.description: Believers are no longer strangers but fellow citizens and members of God’s household, built on the foundation of the apostles and prophets with Christ as the cornerstone.

application: Recognize and rejoice that your salvation is entirely by God’s grace through faith, not by your own efforts.
Live out your identity as a new creation in Christ by pursuing the good works God has prepared for you.
Embrace unity with fellow believers, regardless of background, as Christ has broken down all barriers.
Approach God confidently in prayer, knowing you have access through the one Spirit given by Christ.

keyVerses.text: For by grace are ye saved through faith; and that not of yourselves: it is the gift of God:
keyVerses.significance: This verse clearly teaches that salvation is a gift from God, received by faith, not by human effort.

keyVerses.text: For we are his workmanship, created in Christ Jesus unto good works, which God hath before ordained that we should walk in them.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights that believers are God’s handiwork, created for a purpose to live out good works prepared by Him.

keyVerses.text: For he is our peace, who hath made both one, and hath broken down the middle wall of partition between us;
keyVerses.significance: This verse emphasizes Christ’s role in uniting Jews and Gentiles, breaking down divisions to create peace.

keyVerses.text: Now therefore ye are no more strangers and foreigners, but fellowcitizens with the saints, and of the household of God;
keyVerses.significance: It assures believers of their new identity as members of God’s family and community.
